data.title: Resizing appears jerky/choppy compared to native OSX applications
data.body:
support/a3279f88d15611e386706a28ec238195

> I don't think this is an atom-specific issue, but a node.js/node-webkit issue.
> I noticed resizing an atom window appears 'jerky' or 'choppy' compared to native osx applications like iterm2.
> It appears to be the same in adobe's Brackets editor for example.

...

> Chromium is slightly choppier than Safari/Firefox but not to the same extent as Atom. I noticed Atom’s resizing is quite smooth with only a single tab open, but starts to deteriorate with two or more tabs.

Not sure if there's anything we can do about this, but wanted to create an issue just in case. There _is_ a noticeable difference between resizing native OSX apps and Atom.

Also, possibly related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/929

data.title: Whitespace double click
data.body:
I'm assuming `Cursor::isSurroundedByWhitespace` is supposed to only check the character directly before and directly after the cursor.

Previously it was always checking starting at column 0 for whitespace surrounding the cursor since `Math.min` was being used with `0`.

Now I've removed all range bounds corrections since `TextBuffer::getTextInRange` handles that automatically.

Fixes #1901

data.title: Upgrade to atom-shell@0.12.0
Vertical scrolling with a mouse is too fast, and it's not possible to configure the sensitivity
data.body:
Related to https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1666:
- support/0cfc90ecceb611e39200c9d04f25774f
- support/d6a39d02cc9811e386ac809b029b3fb9

> When using the scroll wheel on my mouse, the editor jumps 8 lines at a time. Any way for me to change this configuration? I would prefer a smooth scroll one line at a time.

...

> The scrolling is not smooth(it would be really nice if it was), and the sensitivity is not adjustable, for me (i have a g500 mouse, the mouse wheel has very little friction) and for me it scrolls to far many lines.

Some users are working around this by hacking on Atom, as described in [this forum thread](http://discuss.atom.io/t/scroll-performance-behavior/291/20):

> If anyone wants to hack this value to slow down scrolling, edit app/src/editor-view.js and find the mousewheel event listener (~line 877) and add a modifier into the delta assignment condition. For example, I edited line 890 to multiply it times .3
> 
> `if (delta = (e.originalEvent.wheelDeltaY * .3)) {`
> 
> Now the speed feels much more natural.

(I don't have a mouse so that I can verify any of this)

data.title: Atom Helpers use up lots of memory and cause performance issues
data.body:
Halp ticket:
- support/86eddc26cb5011e38ee058b670f95585

> I run a retina macbook pro. 16 gig ram, 750 gig ssd, i7. Running atom with even a simple 2-line coffeescript file leads to many atom helper files accumulating, each with a memory allocation of 850 meg or so. When last I tried this out, atom started out fine but as the helper files accumulated and grew larger, the editor slowed to a crawl and my fans started turning at a high rate of speed.

...

> I took the snapshot approximately 10 minutes after loading Atom. Before I started it up, I removed all packages. I have 10 Atom Helper files, 8 of which are 850 meg or so. The other two are smaller. Typing in Atom started great but as the files grew, the overall responsiveness went way down. I had four tabs open: three trivial scripts (two coffeescript, one javascript, each of 3 lines or less) and the settings tab.

The heap snapshot is linked to in the Halp ticket.

cc @nathansobo
